verses.text: So the men of Kiriath-jearim came and took up the Ark of the LORD. They brought it to the house of Abinadab on the hill and consecrated his son Eleazar to guard the Ark of the LORD.
verses.comment: This follows the flow and terms from the original Hebrew; Abinadab's house is on the 'hill' (Heb. gibeah).

verses.text: From the day the Ark stayed at Kiriath-jearim, a long time passed—twenty years—and all the house of Israel lamented and sought after the LORD.
verses.comment: The phrase 'lamented after the LORD' keeps the sense of mourning and longing present in the Hebrew.

verses.text: And Samuel said to all the house of Israel, 'If you are returning to the LORD with all your heart, then remove the foreign gods and the Ashtoreths from among you and direct your hearts to the LORD and serve him only, and he will deliver you out of the hand of the Philistines.'
verses.comment: ‘Ashtoreths’ represents plural of Ashtoreth, accurate to Hebrew; delivered retains sense of rescue.

verses.text: So the sons of Israel removed the Baals and the Ashtoreths and served the LORD alone.
verses.comment: Plural forms for Baals/Ashtoreths keep close to Hebrew, and 'served the LORD alone' is direct.

verses.text: Then Samuel said, 'Gather all Israel at Mizpah, and I will pray to the LORD for you.'
verses.comment: Pray is literal for 'intercede,' and Mizpah is retained as the location name.

verses.text: So they gathered at Mizpah and drew water and poured it out before the LORD. And they fasted that day and said there, 'We have sinned against the LORD.' And Samuel judged the sons of Israel at Mizpah.
verses.comment: Pouring water was a ritual act of repentance. The phrase 'judged' means Samuel acted as leader/judge.

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that the sons of Israel had gathered at Mizpah, the lords of the Philistines went up against Israel. When the Israelites heard it, they were afraid of the Philistines.
verses.comment: ‘Lords’ is the plural for Philistine rulers; language kept direct and clear.

verses.text: And the sons of Israel said to Samuel, 'Do not stop crying out to the LORD our God for us, so that he may save us from the hand of the Philistines.'
verses.comment: ‘Crying out’ is literal for earnest, prayerful pleading to God.

verses.text: So Samuel took a suckling lamb and offered it as a whole burnt offering to the LORD. And Samuel cried out to the LORD for Israel, and the LORD answered him.
verses.comment: ‘Suckling lamb’ is proper translation for young lamb; ‘whole burnt offering’ is literal Hebrew (olah).

verses.text: As Samuel was offering up the burnt offering, the Philistines drew near to attack Israel. But the LORD thundered with a mighty voice against the Philistines that day and confused them, and they were struck down before Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Thundered with a mighty voice’ keeps the dramatic Hebrew imagery; 'confused' is direct for Hebrew 'panim.'

verses.text: And the men of Israel went out from Mizpah and pursued the Philistines, and struck them down as far as below Beth-car.
verses.comment: ‘Struck them down’ is literal and direct; 'below Beth-car' renders the Hebrew place name accurately.

verses.text: Then Samuel took a stone and set it up between Mizpah and Shen and called its name Ebenezer, saying, 'Thus far the LORD has helped us.'
verses.comment: ‘Ebenezer’ means ‘stone of help’; translation is direct and preserves original meaning.

verses.text: So the Philistines were subdued and did not come any more within the border of Israel. And the hand of the LORD was against the Philistines all the days of Samuel.
verses.comment: ‘Subdued’ represents Hebrew for defeated or humbled. 'Hand of the LORD' is biblical idiom for God's power.

verses.text: And the cities which the Philistines had taken from Israel were returned to Israel, from Ekron to Gath. And Israel delivered their territory from the hand of the Philistines. And there was peace between Israel and the Amorites.
verses.comment: ‘Delivered their territory’ communicates restoration; ‘peace with the Amorites’ is direct.

verses.text: And Samuel judged Israel all the days of his life.
verses.comment: ‘Judged’ is literal for Hebrew meaning leader and authority.

verses.text: He went on a circuit year by year to Bethel, Gilgal, and Mizpah, and he judged Israel in all those places.
verses.comment: ‘Circuit’ is literal, showing Samuel’s routine travels as judge.

verses.text: But his home was in Ramah, and there he judged Israel. And he built there an altar to the LORD.
verses.comment: Altar-building is faithful to the Hebrew; Ramah is Samuel’s home, as in original.
